titleStmt.title: Extract of the English Envoy's reply to Count Gollowin's answer dated Mosco 14./25. May 1705
titleStmt.author: Charles
Whitworth

head.title: 14 / 25 May 1705. – Extract of the English Envoy's{{p1255}} reply to Count Gollowin's{{p0277}} answer dated Mosco 14./25. May 1705

note.bibl: NA Kew, Russia, no. SP 91-5, f. 90v-92. English copy.

div.p: Extract of the English Envoy's{{p1255}} reply to Count Gollowin's{{p0277}} answer dated Mosco 14./25. May 1705

To the 3d. As if the Liberty granted to export the produce of their Tobacco Customfree was a particular favour of the Czar{{p0174}}, and no obligation as it is said, the Envoy might see from the words of the original Treaty, is answer’d : The Envoy has consulted the Treaty, and does find that a Liberty was given them to export such returns as they shall think fit, without laying any higher duty thereon than is payd at present by forreign Merchants. Now it is very well known, that by a Custome immemorial no forreign merchant ever did pay any duty for the Exportation of Russian Commodities, which he bought with the produce of such goods as had payd duty at their importation ; the Company{{o0137}} therefor having paid a very high duty for their Tobacco when brought in viz: 4. Copiks p. pound by the natural meaning of that clause they ware Customfree, especially since it was provided by the Treaty that if any difficulty not foreseen may arise in and about the Execution of this present grant, or the Const ruction thereof etc : all matters and things shall be favourably , liberally and beneficially construed and decided in favour and on the part

of the said M ar quis or his assigns. It is likewise very plain, that the Czars Ministers themselves did for two years together own this to be the true intent of the Treaty, since for that time the indisputed liberty was given to export their goods Customfree, nor was it ever mention’d to be a new and particular grace of the Czars{{p0174}} either in the orders themselves, or in any writing, or by word of mouth to Mr. Goodfellow{{p1252}} ; thou had it been one, it was certainly great enough to deserve being insinuated to the Company{{o0137}}, and received by them with all dutyfull acknowledgment : from all which premises the Envoy is oblig’d to insist, that this Exportation Customfree is not a favour, but a justice to the said Company{{o137}}, and therefore he humbly hopes, it may still be complied with.

As to the Letter of Exchange, which Mr. Consul Goodfellow{{p1252}} gave for 20 m. Rubels, it is said, not to have been done by force but voluntarily, in Consideration, that severall parcells of goods ware taken as part of payment for the Tobacco dutys as high rates, and other advantages allowed him and the Company{{o0137}} ; that the said Bill lay a year and a half impay’d, and that it was put to the Tobacco account not at a low but a reasonable price ; to all which is answerd : That the Envoy never said the Bill was taken by

force, but on promise of having ready money immediately pay’d for it, which was not kept. As to the having given free carridges for the Tobacco ; that has hapned very seldome, and in such places, as hoses could not well be hired ; however these and such favours received, Mr. Goodfellow{{p1252}} allways was, and is still ready to acknowledge with his most humble thanks and the respect due to so greate a Prince. As to the not payment of this Bill, the Envoy begs leave to take notice, that there seems to be a small mistake ; for this Bill for 20 m. R Dollars was dated in Decemb[e]r 1702. and was duely pay’d in course ; but Mr. Goodfellow{{p1252}} gave in an other Bill for 24 m. Dollars in May 1703. which for want of a due indorsement was not pay’d till a considerable time afterwards. If this Bill for 20 m. R Dollars was plac’d on the Tobacco account not a t a low but at a reasonable rate, the Envoy hopes no difficulty will be made of having that reasonable rate replac’d by Russian money as it ought, and the Dollars henceforth transferr’d to the account for potash as he at first desir’d.

As to the flax trade it is alleg’d, that this does not concern the Company{{o0137}}, but was given as a particular favour to the consul, with a prospect of increasing the Trade in the Esat Sea, whereof he gave some promices : to this answerd :

that the Envoy never said, this Trade concern’d the Company{{o0137}}, but begs leave to take notice, that there may be probably some little mistake on the second point ; for this patent was granted in July 1702. when the Czar{{p0174}} had no footing in Ingermanland, and much less any Haven on the East Sea ; for Noteburgh was not taken till September 1702. Neuenshantz etc. in 1703. and Narva not till 1704. In the patet it is likewise mention’d to carry out the said flax by way of Archangel, which was the a great piece of service, none having been ever sent thither before, and lastly the Consul{{p1252}} had much ado, to obtain that the Town of Narva should likewise be inserted in his grant, in hopes a peace might be made before that was expired : however since His Excellence declares, that the common dutys ware onely order’d to be taken from him, and not the new additional impositions, the Envoy has nothing to desire, but that His Excellencys orders to this purpose may be signifyed to the Precasse{{o0064}}, in the usuall manner.
